This is the sort of thing I was hoping for.  

Is the tool that manages the variables completely separate from Test 
Mentor?  

With JUnit as it is, it seems there's no way to internally handle 
passing around state info from the TestSuite's TestSetup.

I suppose a singleton TestListener could keep track of test start/end 
and have methods like getLocalVar(name) and setLocalVar(name,value).  

Does anybody have anything like this?  Does it sound like the right 
thing to do?  The tmp file solution may be more expedient.

-Kevin



--- In junit@y..., "Michael Silverstein" <msilverstein@s...> wrote:
> We do the following with Test Mentor (a commercial component testing 
tool),
> but you could probably extend JUnit in a similar way:
> 
> We provide a sort of managed variable scheme within the context of 
an
> executing test, respective of scope (tests in Test Mentor can be 
recursively
> defined, if you like), that's basically a bunch of 
java.util.Hashtables,
> each tied to a particular scoping level. These Hashtable values are
> accessible by APIs within the tool that resolve the correct value, 
depending
> on the context of the executing test. The APIs  make it pretty 
transparent,
> relying mostly on a test execution context stack that tracks 
whichever
> Hashtable should be active at the moment. The APIs (which any test 
inherits)
> look something like getLocalVar(name) and setLocalVar(name,value). 
So you
> could instantiate/execute a test that sets variables, which then
> instantiates/exeuctes another test within it that may or may not set
> variables with the same name, and the tool will handle variable name 
scope
> resolution automatically.
